review_title: Right place, wrong time. Nothing personal.
job_title: Head Office Employee in Welwyn Garden City, England
pros: Lovely people, very clear collective passion for the industry and the services provided.
cons: Young company experiencing "growing pains". Poor quality of data. Inadequate systems. Org structure has too many blurred lines. Suffers from bureaucracy of wider industry.

job_title: SERVICE ADVISOR in Bedford, England
pros: Variety Good friendly team Always someone to help if you need it Overtime Able to browse internet between calls Local shop short walk
cons: Can get boring as not allowed phones. Shift timings can be inflexible. Office equipment and furniture needs upgrading, picking the wrong chair can cause back ache. No home working. Late nights. No food on site. Working late means you won't see a senior manager.

review_title: Ok company to work for but not a career
job_title: Shift Manager in Peterborough, England
pros: Good team of people to work with on shift. Lots of overtime to the point of being harassed even when in holiday to do more hours.
cons: Trying to be too big too quick, not people focussed. Bullying is accepted by senior management and not acted on when reported. Call centre managers are unprofessional and you only progress if your face fits or you are friends with the management in head office.

job_title: SERVICE ADVISOR in Bedford, England
pros: Co- workers were all helpful
cons: Management act as if it’s a constant issue coming to them

job_title: Administrative in Welwyn Garden City, England
pros: Worked here for a few years now Things improving slowly in certain areas others less so Office environment has improved and better rest areas for 111 staff
cons: Basic rate pay for most staff not good enough Focus on other departments not just 111

review_title: Not a great company to work for
job_title: Administration Assistant in Welwyn Garden City, England
pros: Helping people when they are sick is rewarding
cons: Management doesn't care for anyone on the ground only themselves. They pay their staff really badly. Often minimum wage. Don't care about the people who actually do the work.

job_title: Dental Nurse in Welwyn Garden City, England
pros: Flexible hours, for around childcare
cons: Not huge amounts of hours available. No where to refer patients

job_title: NHS 111 Health Advisor in Peterborough, England
pros: Overtime if wanted, onsite parking.
cons: Worst company I have ever worked for, the organisation is awful and communication is terrible, they regularly get pay wrong, this happens on a monthly basis. No respect for staff at all.

job_title: Driver/Receptionist in Cambridge, England
pros: OK hourly rate for amount of work expected.
cons: Holiday very difficult to get approved. Isolated working locations, usually only working with a clinician, can be quite lonely.

job_title: NHS 111 Call Handler in Hemel Hempstead, England
pros: Every day is different and challenging
cons: The management don’t care you are just another number

job_title: Health Advisor in Peterborough, England
pros: If you thrive when micromanaged you'll relish the role.
cons:
You expected to turn up early so you can logon and take a call the minute your shifts starts. That’s 10 to 15 minutes unpaid. Your expected to take calls until 1 minute before your shift ends. So you’ll finish around 15 minutes late (unpaid). You can’t take time out to read emails but are allowed to stay behind and read them in your own time (unpaid). You have 30 seconds between calls. 

Chatting to colleagues is “discouraged”. 

Too many of the low level management are miserable, soul destroying and petty. Some are genuinely great people but when you turn up and find the miserables on shift your heart sinks. 

They are hot on you wearing masks, no jeans, no trainers nor mobiles but these rules don’t seem to apply to management as they wander around the office.

If somebody calls 111 by mistake (maybe they wanted test and trace or have a question about the NHS app) you are told to open a case (NHS pays them by the case) and assess them although they have no symptoms, so they can charge the NHS. Keeping them on the phone for 10 minutes only to tell them to go to NHS.UK website. You do have to pass yourself of as NHS although this is a private company that 111 is outsourced to.

Everything you say is recorded. Auditors listen to however many calls they want and choose which ones to audit. Face don’t fit they choose your bad ones. Face fits they choose your good ones. Though to be honest I was truly awful.

Very occasionally they provided free food. But don’t let you know so by the time you see it your pizza is cold.

Guidance is very inconsistent. So you take guidance from one “expert” and YOU get marked down on audit because another “expert” disagrees with them.

There is a cadre of employees who have been there since they started on 111 and if your happy to cow towel to them you’ll get on great. 

You’re paid £9.90 an hour whilst on probation which will last at least 6 months (understand a pay rise is imminent so they don’t go below min. wage). 

Once I was told to take a 20 minute break after a difficult call. Pay docked for those 20 minutes. You’ll also be spammed most days with texts asking you to do extra hours.
